div.div: φίλος , comp. φιλίων and φίλτερος, sup. φίλτατος, voc. at the beginning of the verse φῖλε: own, dear, but it must not be supposed that the first meaning has not begun everywhere in Homer to pass into the stage of the latter, hence neither Eng. word represents its force in many instances, φίλα εἵματα, φίλος αἰών, and of parts of the body, φίλαι χεῖρες, etc. Pl. φίλοι, dear ones, friends, one's own, Od. 4.475. Neut., φίλον, φίλα, pleasing, acceptable; φίλον ἔπλετο θῡμῷ, αἰεί τοι τὰ κάκ᾽ ἐστὶ φίλα φρεσὶ μαντεύεσθαι, you like to, Il. 1.107 ; φίλα φρονεῖν, εἰδέναι τινί, be kindly disposed, Il. 4.219, Od. 3.277.
From A Homeric Dictionary (Georg Autenrieth, New York, Harper and Brothers, 1891)
